review_title: Amazing potential to do exciting work. Sadly, not delivered.
job_title: Employee, RNLI International Team in Poole, England
pros:
RNLI International occupies a unique space full of opportunity to really make a difference, really exciting chances to build creative partnerships across different organisations and cultures, and many ways to be very influential. This is , sadly, all lost through awful management and recruitment of staff (men) based on personal friendships, plus a really colonial and disrespectful attitude to working with international partners. 

There are a few good people, but the overwhelming culture is toxic.

RNLI pensions benefits are amazing
cons:
-A number of 'Head of Team' positions, who only manage a couple of people, receiving huge salaries, for doing relatively little, with no people management skills. Managers on equivalent salary scales in the rest of the organisation could be managing 50-100 people. Charity money wasted on a number of very highly paid staff with few responsibilities, and low capacity.
-Inability to take management decisions
-Good staff get disheartened and leave quickly
-Lack of collaboration
-Defensive culture 
-Lack of intelligent analysis
-Horrible / patronising attitude towards women in the team, and with international partners. Very little understanding of cultural issues, or gender issues.

job_title: International Programmes Officer in Poole, England

Inability to manage a change process to improve the team- after a long , expensive and exhausting 'change process', there were no changes to the skills or culture of the team.
Jobs given to (male) friends, despite not having the right profile for the work
No understanding of gender issues in projects or in the office: culture of male banter and jokes about women, bullying and low-level aggression

review_title: Great Institution,  Work Culture Sadly Toxic in some Teams
pros: Great institution to work for, wonderful variety of colleagues, some very talented and skilled at their job and it is privilege to work along these folk as well as volunteers .  Opportunities to get involved in events and also be be trained to excel at your job as well as other learning resources as part of appraisal scheme.  If you work at the main support centre it is based in central Poole which is accessible by Public Transport (see cons).  The pension is an excellent benefit.  Less pressured than commercial world.
cons: Restricted parking on site and elaborate parking scheme in place which is officious and bureaucratic. It can make working life difficult and more expensive.  Unfortunately your experience can vary greatly by what team you work in.  Administration is an area which needs attention as many talented folk end up leaving or switch roles at the earliest opportunity.  There are also behaviours which are not consistent with RNLI values and they create a toxic work environment.  This is a great pity as the Institution is very worthy and it's Admin staff are the small cogs which make the big stuff happen.

pros: work at a beach all the time :)
cons: could have done more to support lifeguards in lockdown, as did not pursue furlough scheme, meaning many lifeguards had no income whatsoever/

job_title: FACE To FACE FUNDRAISER in Newcastle, England
pros: Good values and good management team

pros: Rewarding, outside work, everyday is different
cons: Lack of availability for progression

pros:
Working with the RNLI as a lifeguard is a fantastic job, for many reasons: it is an 
established and well-recognised charity; the work is mainly outdoors; fitness tests provide an incentive to remain fit and healthy; great equipment is provided for you as part of the  contract; fellow staff were generally good fun to work with; the salary is very good (especially for teenagers and students); the training is top-class.
cons:
I am sorry to say that progress in the organisation generally depends more on who you know (and whose backside you are prepared to kiss) than your ability and qualifications. This probably stems in part from the fact that when the RNLI set up its lifeguarding structure, all of the areas were managed by a kind-of "old boys club" and, although this structure has been shaken up recently, blatant nepotism exists in the organisation (at least in N.I.) up to a high level. 

It is a shame that nepotistic tendencies have permeated the managerial and supervisory structures. On many occasions, tensions between lifeguards and between certain lifeguards and supervisors existed for long periods, often unresolved.

Additionally, those in positions of command (supervisors and managers) are basically unaccountable, making it difficult for staff with genuine grievances to address them.

pros: The purpose - who wouldn't want to be involved in helping to save lives? Nice location. Brilliant culture at stations and the lower levels of HQ. Some unbelievably committed people doing a great job in difficult circumstances.
cons: An obsession by top management with saving money by implementing lean methods. Good idea but overdone and without good cause. RNLI incomes is still increasing even with the economic climate. Some very poor directors who do not match the quality of staff lower down.

job_title: Area Lifesaving Manager in South Shields, England
pros: working for an organisation with a clear sense of purpose
cons: wide and varied focus and skillset required working in many different streams

review_title: Honourable cause, great teams but needs to modernise
pros: Flexible working, for some there's great autonomy and an aspiration to be a progressive employer. It's multi-faceted and there's lots of different types of roles here. Dedicated volunteers are at the heart of the charity. There's courage to do the right thing. The Chief Executive is inspiring, a great communicator and encourages openness and trust. It's great to work for a company that does good in the world.
cons: Bit old fashioned in some of the ways of working making it feel overly bureaucratic. The values are great but not always role modelled - both staff and volunteers. There's always too much to do and some of this is due to the way we set ourselves up or how we do things. There's an appetite to do great things and to become more progressive which is admirable but this can often end up as giving people more work to do. The 'rescue' aspect seems to be in the DNA which can be massively positive in a rescue situation but can drive a reactive and 'saviour' type mindset and culture.

job_title: Face to Face in Poole, England
pros: I had the chance to work with some amazing people who fast became friends. It was a great job for the summer between my first, second and third years of university. We were paid above minimum wage, had access to a hire car for group use, worked on the beach and at events talking to hundreds of people from all backgrounds each day.
cons: When I originally applied for the job I thought I would be spreading sea safety messages. There was no clear mention of face to face fundraising and signups. This only became apparent during on the job training at the start of season which left me feeling a bit duped. There were targets to be met in how many ‘sign ups’ we got per day and employees that weren’t meeting targets were asked to leave. However with the reputation of face to face fundraisers being so poor and in the press during that summer it was difficult to convince people we were trustworthy meaning the public were reluctant to sign up to support even though they had been convinced by us that it was an essential service in the uk.

pros: Free coffee in HQ building, nice locations around the coast, some genuinely nice people with big hearts that work at the coalface.
cons: Poor management, poor middle leadership and a continuous cycle of changes without evaluating and monitoring whether the previous change had been successful.  Highly wasteful organisation that runs programmes and projects poorly, frequently overspending and under-delivering.  This leads to a culture of low morale amongst staff, that is exasperated by the lack of a professional, emotionally intelligent approach, to people and inclusion.

pros: There are some great people that are truly committed to delivering the service – Saving Lives a at Sea.  These dedicated people willingly go that extra mile knowing what they do makes a difference and it’s a real honour to work with such people.  In the main this group is head office middle management and is far reaching right out to the coastal employees and the volunteers at Lifeboat stations.
cons: The business has lost its direction which is down to very poor leadership - Trying to do too many things at any one time. The majority of the Directors and senior management have little understanding about return on investment, sadly wasting money, voluntary contributions that are extremely hard to come by in these frugal times

pros: The people are very friendly and are accommodating.
cons: Understaff and full of politics. The org's structure is not helping to work collaboratively. You are expected to work more for less at the expense of your own health or sanity. Snr leadership are so terrible and hardly in touch to their direct reports. Information and feedback from the bottom are not necessarily sent back to the top.

review_title: Good benefits and fun, gets patronising if you don’t hit targets
pros: The benefits for the f2f role are great really. Free accommodation, access to hire cars and good rate of pay. Great for the CV and if you get a good team and senior fundraiser you’re set for a good summer.
cons: If you fall below target you’re made to feel stupid. I didn’t personally need to be put on performance improvement but one guy I was with did - he was hired with no relevant experience and was expected to be hitting targets asap. However you need to be making back the money they spend on you so it’s partially justified.

pros: People, and purpose of organisation
cons: A lack of clear direction from senior managers
